Description: Slightly curved tapering bronze knife with a duck-head tang/handle.
Curator's comments: Egyptian scribes used delicate bronze knives such as these for trimming their brushes, for cutting stalks of papyrus to size before pressing them together into sheets, and for cutting the sheets to the required size for working on. The handles of these examples end in a duck’s head, a type which is depicted in the tomb of Rekhmire at Thebes (c. 1425 BC). Actual examples have been found in the tombs of Neferkhaut and Hatiay at Thebes, and also in tombs at Abydos.
See also 1956,1015.1 See also 1956,1015.2 All three are described in Christie's auction catalogue 27 July 1956, lot 72, as 'said to have been found in a tomb at Thebes, Upper Egypt, 1826.'
